title: Quiz 8: Social Change & Development
description: Exploring theories, causes, barriers, and elements of social change.

questions.question: Which theory of social change suggests that society moves from simple to complex in a specific forward direction (evolutionary)?
questions.explanation: Linear theory views change as evolutionary and progressive towards betterment.

questions.question: Which of the following are elements of social change? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: All listed options (Environment, Tech, Population, Institutions) are key drivers/elements of change.
questions.hint: All of them play a role.

questions.question: Match the theory of social change with its core concept:

pairs.right: Societies rise, decline, and rise again

questions.explanation: Conflict = struggle; Cyclic = circle; Functionalism = balance; Modernization = copying west.
questions.hint: Link the name to the mechanism.

questions.question: Order the stages of a social movement:
___BLANK___ refers to any significant alteration over time in behavior patterns, cultural values, and norms.
questions.explanation: This is the definition of Social Change.

questions.question: What are common barriers to social change? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Tradition, fear of losing power (vested interests), and cost hinder change. Innovation PROMOTES change.

questions.question: Social change is a rare event that happens only once every few centuries.
questions.explanation: False. Social change occurs ALL THE TIME, though it may be slow or imperceptible.

questions.question: Which concept describes the unintended negative consequences of development projects (e.g., dams causing disease)?
questions.explanation: Large-scale projects can introduce new health risks (e.g., standing water causing malaria/schistosomiasis), termed 'diseases of development'.

questions.question: What term describes the situation where a population is relocated due to development projects?
questions.explanation: Displacement or relocation often accompanies large projects like dams.

questions.question: Monoculture (growing a single cash crop) can lead to malnutrition in families despite increased income.
questions.explanation: True. Focus on cash crops reduces food crop diversity and availability for the family, leading to 'pockets of malnutrition'.
